description.text: I wrote a php file to convert all the airfoils from the http://www.ae.illinois.edu/m-selig/ads/coord_database.html ( about 1550 or so ) to scad and sdl files ( taking there cordanence, writing them to a openscad polygon, then using liner_extrude to make it 3d,

I had to edit my base plate temp to 120c in order to make it not curl,
I am not sure if that is just my replicator thought The 7z file has all but the last 800 or so, I am going to bed now and it still is running so I wanted to upload what I have now, just incase anyone wanted to use them, I did a spot check of them and i would say 50% or so are ready to print another 25% need some minor tweeking on the bracket placement, and the other 25% are unusable Also I uploaded the php file I used to create them, to run it you will need php installed ( and in the command path ) along with openscad installed, and change the path of openscad if it is not the same as what I have I put the full database under a new thing
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25170

description.text:
I redesigned the 3DR Simple (http://trains.socha.com/2013/09/3dr-simple-delta-printer-part-i.html)end effector for use with a J-Head. I don't have a Printrbot Simple hot end and had a few J-Heads on hand. This particular design is for a TriDPrinting.com J-Head. My MakerFarm J-Heads are slightly different, for instance, and will require a different mounting plate. Vitamins List
3 M3 x 20 socket head cap screws
3 M3 nuts
1 M5 nut
1 Push Fit Pneumatic Bushing for 4mm OD tube, 5mm thread
TriDPrinting J-Head (at least the PEEK body)

Print the new platform and the J-Head holder plate.   
Use a torch or high heat to heat the M5 nut and then sink it into the hex recess on the top of the platform. It's better to have metal threads for mechanical strength. The hex recess was purposefully printed small to allow a very tight fit with heat. You must use heat because the recess is too tight for just a press fit.   
Assembly the J-Head, mounting plate and platform together.  
Install into your 3DR Simple and enjoy.

comments.text: Sorry for taking so long to respond on this. The hex hole for the nut is so tight that it required heating of the nut and then pressing in. I haven't used the 3DR much since I built it 2 months ago since I have been away for work. I have gone through some calibration "printing" with it and nothing has happened WRT to the nut. You can pull on it quite heavily and it won't budge.
comments.author: Apru

comments.text: Have you had any problems with the press-fit nut pulling out?

comments.text: Hey! I've been away from Thingiverse for a while but I'm so happy to see all the awesome data you're mapping with this thing. Let me know if you have any particular feature requests or other feedback.
comments.author: anoved

comments.text:
Hi! Yeah I've been having altogether too much fun with this map, I made a spreadsheet to organize and collect all the data:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1BPs7SZWTCTRb0EH6R1Yj5NUnEoc3RnvHbZtNWqKDhIM/edit#gid=0
The script you wrote for the map of the US works great in customizer, haven't had it break or output a non-printable model on me yet. If you would be up for expanding to even more countries around the world I think people would get a lot of use out of those maps too.
It's great to have a physical map to show people, they seem to engage with the information in a different way when they can hold it and squish it and bend it (I've printed all mine in ninjaflex). Really good stuff!

description.text:
My brothers just moved into their apartment which is right across the hall from me. They had a few shelves that didn't have the supports for them in their cupboard.

I took one of the existing plastic parts from their cupboard and modeled it identically to what they were using.

You might need to shrink the length of the peg to a little under 6mm long and just a tad under 6mm for the diameter.

My printer is not working the best, due to experimenting with it too much, so it made the pegs a little lop-sided, which made it a tight fit.

I've included the Fusion file so you can customize it yourself. :)

Worked like a charm!

title: Handle for Under Armour water bottle

description.text:
I have an Under Armour water bottle. It's ok, but the handle is really thin, which makes it uncomfortable to carry especially if it's full of water.

I designed this handle to fit over the existing handle and make it more comfortable to hold. I wrapped it with grip tape after to hold it in place and make it a little softer.

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Don't change the orientation. it needs a little strength in 2 dimensions so it doesn't crack, this orientation puts the weak dimension where it doesn't matter.

I printed with a tiny bit of support, not sure how it'll print without any support.

author: Reoost

description.text:
This is an Extended Grip for the Sony A7R2 Camera but should fit any Sony A7, except the new a7R3.
The Grip on the Sony A7 only has room for three fingers the grip will allow you to use your little finger too. It is a help when using a large heavy lens and might offer some impact protection.

This is based on the "J.B. Camera Designs Pro Bamboo Grip-Base for Sony A7" Which is much nicer so if you like this you might spend the US $60 for the real one.
The pictures were taken before it was cleaned up have to remember to do that first next time.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

not important

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You will have to print this standing on its back edge, vertically and use supports in the holes.
I just used the automatic supports in the Craft slicer and it worked perfect.

you will have to do some clean up do to the supports.
you will need a tripod screw to attach it to the camera (1/4" 20) make sure it is long enough.
a thought would be to coat it in liquid rubber.

Water, water everywhere…REFLEX SAVE!

This water shrine is full of small things to delight even the most detail-oriented gamer. Check out the Elder Futhark rings along the archway that say “Water.” The water symbols inset into the floor and side walls are excellent for rituals or, if you’re feeling more devious, traps.

The third in the encounters series, this is a shrine to water. We have both a cut stone and rough stone versions. The elemental symbol is inspired by the elemental symbols from Avatar: Last Airbender.

In this release we have:

  • Walls with the water rune
  • Floors with the water rune
  • Pillars that say "Water" in runic futhark
  • A roman archway with water themed archwork
  • An alter to water that also works as a wall fountain. This piece has a bunch of water themed elements, including the at sea and big wave icons from game-icons.net.

To find the curved pieces, you can get them in:

  • Cut Stone: curved
  • Rough Stone: curved

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook
You can find other sets in the OpenForge Encounters line in this collection

There are eight dowel segments that you must fit into a box. You should be able to get seven pieces in with ease. What about the last piece?

This very simple project was built from scrap wood (minimal cost) and it took about an hour. STP/STL files are included for those that would like to print a version. I tested the puzzle on my two teenage children and both gave up after 5 minutes so I would say it’s slightly challenging.

Link to Amazon version: http://amzn.to/2hL9gHH

I understand the originator of this logic puzzle was Tesa Timonen of Sweden in 2002. I reversed engineered this version from online pictures.

More Info: https://www.instructables.com/id/Wood-Dowel-Puzzle/
Video Solution:https://youtu.be/NXJTk96OiWc

author: HRange

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

title: AM8 Multi X Axis Mounts  (17mm and 21mm for now)

description.text:
The AM8 is one of the best upgrades to have come out out of the Anet A8 community. It a easy, cheap, frame upgrade that helps improve your prints due to a wobbly frame. Not only is it cheap to due, but it is a very easy upgrade.
The best part about the AM8 is it's capability to be easily modified. It allows for different sized beds to be put in place as well as a whole series of other mods that can be put on it as well due to its design. You can also re-use a majority of your old printers part to put it together, saving even more money.
The creator of the AM8 (pheneeny) mentions in his description that he wanted to appeal to a wide spread audience. I want to help pheneeny by helping expand from the Anet community, to more communities. This is a great frame upgrade and I want more people to experience it.

One of the ways we can help spread this out, is by creating parts and modifying parts to help other users. The more parts we can recycle, the better and easier it is for everyone. One of the things I noticed is that different printers come with difference distances between the Smooth rods and the threaded rods.
I have already made modifications to the parts and re-created the rod holders to allow for different distances to be able to fit on the frame. The distance between the smooth rods and lead screw for the Anet A8 is 22 mm. I have made changes to allow motor mounts that use a 17mm distance and motor mounts that use a 21mm distance to be able to use this frame by just downloading the necessary parts and using these parts instead of the orignal AM8 parts.
This should allow a drop in place version for the X axis instead of having to buy new rods and printing new motor mounts.

I definitely recommend heading to the AM8 page and reviewing everything.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2263216

When switching over, some things need to be changed from the original build guide. The Anet A8 and the AM8 both use 380mm smooth rods for the Y axis. The guide for the Y axis tells you to purchase 2 Extrusions of 340 mm.
The Prusa i3 uses 350mm smooth rods, thus you will need to purchase 310mm aluminum extrusions. For the Y-axis, you order 40mm less aluminum extrusions then what the size of your smooth rods are. This is basic math and I could be wrong. It would be nice to hear some input for people.

For the x axis, the Anet A8 uses 436mm smooth rods, thus for the AM8 you will need to purchase 3 extrusions of 313mm. If your X axis smooth rods length are different, then you will definietly need to order 3 extrusions of a different size.
The Prusa i3 uses 370mm smooth rods for the x axis. I recommended ordering 3x 247mm extrusions. That is 123mm less then what your x axis smooth rods are. Like mentioned before, I would like to hear if this is correct.

This is still a work in progress and I am sure people will run into some trouble, but if we comment and post, I am sure we can find solutions to them and create parts to help that. Since I only have two printers which both currently have metal frames, I am limited on the testing I can do on my side. Please let me know anything that needs to be changed in the comment sections.

Thank you

title: Modern Phone and Tablet Stand Design!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Again, necessity is the mother of invention and the father, well that is up to Maury Povich to determine. Yet this niffy little gadget was inspired by this design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2283017) yet I flipped it around, added another slot and holes and well made it different from scratch. So from me to you as an STL gift as this is works well for phones and small tablets (larger ones are likely too top heavy).

Also there is a bonus here! Use feet such as these http://amzn.to/2xpsXvo and you can run a charging / sync cable underneath and up through the holes! How cool is that for one a part simple print with no support to worry about!

These also make great Christmas gifts too, so order a lot of filament and start printing to keep with your families demand as don't forget our motto! You can't print just one!

Major Favor: if you make one of these please post a MAKE and share it with the community :-) .

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

Printer:

Any 200mm x 200mm printer will work

No

No

.3 or better you pick

20% (or abouts)

No muss or fuss, simply slice, print and enjoy! Also don't for get the feet (http://amzn.to/2xpsXvo) for added cable bonus!

print_settings.Notes:: You make the part like shown in Cura view with 1cm grids so that the groves print well. You may have to rotate the stl design to print like this but is is important.

description.text:
Motor bracket for use on small 3mm shaft robotics motors sold on pololu.com and other sites.

The bracket is shown upside down and is printed upside down for best print.

The holes work great for M2.5 and a 4-40 will work if your printer is fine resolution but if your resolution is not very good you will have to drill out the holes and in fact the slots may not print clean in that case either.

WARNING: You need to have a very fine resolution printer most likely with 0.4mm nozzle to print the slots properly. They turn out great using my printer type shown below.

Set model like shown in 'Cura' image by rotating it as shown and make a part. For the bracket on the other side of the robot mirror the design in Cura or other slicer so motor bracket slots are for other side wheel.

Best to use near 100% fill so if you want you can cut off with mill or saw or file after the print and use shorter scews optionally. One picture shows motor mounted with modified bracket for shorter screws but I had not used 100% fill which would look nicer.

If you find this is useful feel free to drop a comment or even a small gratuity using the thingiverse paypal gratuity system OR since that has a rather high minimum of $3 (too much) you may use bitcoin address 1yKJcrkLE7RmsLmZPL3ku5PpazGzNmDSS or Ethereum address 0xbCCEf017Ff00215496A768fb0238893Edf7584B0 if you are setup for crypto transfers. Mostly I want this to be helpful to people using these motors.

Create Forever!
Mark
www.mark-world.com

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.4mm extruder

Infill:

80%

Notes:

This part requires a printer with fine nozzle such as 0.4mm I think in order to print the very narrow groves for the motor plates. The part looks really nice on my printer with 0.4mm nozzle and very fine print resolution.

I actually have Monoprice Maker Select Ultimate but it is for the most part exactly like the Wanhao Duplicator 6 and the selections do not show my printer.

Use a high infill if you want to mill off or saw off the area with screws to use shorter screws.

You make the part like shown in Cura view with 1cm grids so that the groves print well. You may have to rotate the stl design to print like this but is is important.

I noticed that when lowering my z axis, the nut was coming out of the x axis injected molded idler end. Unless I pushed down on the end before my print started, to reset the nut into place, it would cause the first layer not to stick well.

The smaller piece fits against the bottom of the nut with the nubs up, and the bigger piece holds it in place.

This is for a Prusa i3 clone with injected molded parts. The z screw it a 5mm threaded rod.

title: Bicycle holder for a Sony Xperia Z1

description.text:
A bike holder for a Sony Xperia Z1. I use it to play Ingress when going to work... Of course it's also handy to have any kind of GPS apps running to guide your way or to provide statistics about your trip.  
The phone is held really tight by the holder. I don't fear that the phone might fall down. Also, so far there are no scratches on the phone. Therefore, in the end, I'm quite happy with the holder.  
Use four bolts (40mm x 4mm) with nuts and washers to connect the two pieces on the handle bar. If it does not fit tight, you can put some rubber (band) between the holder and the handlebar.  
If your handlebar has a different diameter than mine (22.4 mm for me), you can easily change the diameter in the OpenSCAD file.

Use four bolts (40mm x 4mm) with nuts and washers to connect the two pieces on the handle bar. If it does not fit tight, you can put some rubber (band) between the holder and the handlebar.  
If your handlebar has a different diameter than mine (22.4 mm for me), you can easily change the diameter in the OpenSCAD file.

title: Delving Decor: Basic Ruin Walls (28mm/Heroic scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
These modular slide/snap-fit wall tiles will quickly add cover and volume to your gaming table, and utilize a special connector system we've developed for a full range of dungeon tiles and modular architecture sets we'll soon be offering for sale (and as exclusive rewards to our Patreon Subscribers).

IMPORTANT PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS - These models are designed to get the most out of your print time/material, plus the connectors may be optimized for this set up as well (still hashing all that out). When you print, do so at 0% infill and 2 shells (I do a .2 layer height) and use a raft if you need to (no supports are required). Also, I tend to stagger mine by about 15 degrees and that helps avoid curling (if that's an issue for you).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

author: Lanfer234

description.text: Made with an PP3DP MIni UP ! in white ABS dia 1,75 mm
Needed a sturdier way to attach a rope to my lollypop sign

When changing filaments on an octopi I don't have any macros setup for changing filaments, so instead I made a knob to jog the un-powered extruder to help load new filaments through a printrbot simple metal. This goes directly on the exposed dshaft of the stepper motor. For those of you who find the lever on the extruder difficult to push down, this jogger knob will save you the effort. Please use common sense and keep foreign objects/upgrades away from the now moving part if you decide to leave it in. It is made so that it has a snug fit for long term and you can pull it out without any setscrews.

title: Gate Latch for 0.5" No Dig Gate

description.text:
Remixed version of the latch lock by anmael. I scaled the base up, added bars to clamp around a 0.5" no dig gate that I have and reinforced those bars. In addition, I increased the diameter of the circle cover stop and lengthened the hook to 3.5".

Make sure you print the base as oriented in the STL file for maximum strength (with supports). It will break off pretty easily if not.

This project was to keep my dogs contained in my back yard, and after many revisions it is proving to be successful! Let me know if you try it out!

I recently purchased some POM nuts from RobotDigg, but noticed they only had 3 mounting holes. Since I am running a custom MK2 clone, I wanted something close to the original with little modification,

Enter the new x ends. This is a modification of the x-ends from the prusa openscad files to include a 3mm hole on one side (normal) and a 2mm hole on the other.

With the help of a small hand drill, you can pop a new hole in the 3 holed POM nut without compromising its structural integrity.

Needed:
2x POM nuts from RobotDigg. (25.4mm flange, 19.05mm center-to-center screw hole spacing, 12.7mm OD of throat for leadscrew)
2x m3x12 screws
2x m3 nuts
2x m2x12 screws
2x m2 nuts
(+Other screws/parts/etc that make up the Prusa X-Ends)

Included are my modifications to the x-ends.scad file, and resulting STLs for the ends. As well as modifications to the leadscrew covers with modified screws for TR8x2, TR8x4 and TR8x8 leadscrews.

I also added in comments and variables for anyone wishing to tweak settings.
You will need to grab a copy of the following files from the Prusa github:
bearing.scad
polyholes.scad
x-end-idler.scad
x-end-motor.scad

Releasing under GNU GPL v3 as that is what the original scad files from Prusa are.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Drill a hole in the POM nut

Use one of the ends as a guide.

Use a small 1/16in or 2mm drill bit and hand drill a hole in the POM nut after tightening down the m3 screw on the opposite side.

Take your time, and mind the surface under the part (I may have put a hole or two into my counter top)

So when I got into 3d printing I had already had in interest in robotics. So while learning to CAD I decided to give my go at designing some kind of humanoid bi-ped. Couple goals was to be simple and cheap. Even at 12 DOF and being close to actual human movement I believe I achieved that goal (maybe).

Hardware -

Servos - Designed from the ground up using cheapo RC servos, I used the MG996.
Screws - I found some pretty cheap "laptop screws" m2x5
Drill bit - To pre drill the screw holes. I purchased a 1.6mm at Home Depot
Controller of your choice -
(see pretty simple)

Printing -

Unfortunately when I designed this thing, I did not take into account for ease of 3d printing. Also when I exported the STLs I did not orientate them for printing. They are exported as in the model. You will need to orientate them for what works best for you, and you will need to use supports. Print the leg 4 times. and print everything else once.

Assembly -

The servos were designed to mount flush to the brackets. So if you decide to use the rubber mounts, you will need to cut the back off so the tabs sit flush. Once the servos are mounted, you will take the nest piece, slide it over the servo end first and then connect the rear pivot. At which point you will then use your controller to center the servo - attach the servo horn while aligning the pieces to predrill your screw holes. Then screw the servo horn to the piece.

My original thoughts were to use an Arduino Mega with a servo shield and a RC UBEC. But after I got done building the legs, I realized my "Hello World" coding skills were not up to the task of getting this thing to walk lol. So on the back shelf it went. But here it is, maybe some of you know how to get it up and running. Feel free to message or comment!

..........................................................................................................................

The leg piece I noticed is a different STL than the picture. Ill see if I can get some time and update the STL. This monstrosity was designed in Sketch-up so if maybe you want the save file to continue the project, let me know.

comments.text:
A few problems ....
1) Hips are too far apart. The torque on the motors is 11 kg/cm. Some people think this will lift 11 kg but the real interpretation is that it will lift 11 kg within 1 cm radius. The hip motors were 11 cm apart. The motors are not strong enough to lift one leg so I've closed the legs a little to 6 cm apart. This has made a slight improvement.
2) These motors are not of good quality. That's why they're cheap. They have too much 'play' which makes it rather difficult for the 'limbs' to keep in a set position.
3) I'll persevere but it may come down to a) bringing the height down by taking out the motors for the knees therefore reducing the weight, b) buying more expensive motors which means starting all over again with the design measurements.

comments.author: InfinityFrog

comments.text:
Oh no, sorry about that!
I completely forgot about it in my original write up, but I did have to do some hand-finishing to get it all together. I used a Dremel to cut away the inner wall to allow enough room for the overhanging parts of the stick's base. I used a countersinking drill bit on some of the screw holes to make them flush or recessed as necessary. I'm certain the screws holding the plate fit for me, but there's always a chance they changed to shorter ones.
Regarding the buttons, ideally they'll press-fit snugly, but there's a very fine line for making that happen. I printed it in two different colors of PLA from the same manufacturer, and one was perfect while the other was a little loose. I sparingly applied hot glue to the loose one and it never gave me any trouble.
Regarding Tinkercad, I'm sorry to say I've never used it so I can't be any help there.

Using this plug, you can store stuff inside the steerer tube of a mountain bike. This is the hollow space inside the headtube of the bike. The plug goes in the underside of the steerer (top of the fork). It will fit a 1.5" tapered head tube. On my bike this gives approximately 1.25 x 5.5 inch cylinder of storage space. I can fit a CO2 inflation and a couple of thin tire levers.

If you don't want to print with flexible material for the 'seal', you can use some rubber o rings or a piece of foam cut into a ring shape. I tired this and it worked well with all three seal solutions.

The bolt I used is a 3mm (M3 x 15mm). I used two nuts but there are a few ways you could do this. Print the wing nut if you want to make it 'tool-less' to open.
solidworks

description.text:
This print is ready to go and does not need any more fixing to be printed!
her leg got a little gouged up due to a support fusing to it, i updated the model to fix this.

3D Print Ruby Rose here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2357481
3D Print Weiss Schnee here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397963
3D Print Blake here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2447958
3D Print Yang here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2471634
Join the Anime Figure group and share and print anime figures! https://www.thingiverse.com/groups/animefigures
Support me on Patreon! https://www.patreon.com/AnimuAnimu/posts

This print already has all the support material ready to go, DO NOT add SUPPORT MATERIAL.
the support material that i already added to the file has tapered ends and easily breaks off, however be very careful removing, especially around the head. no cutting or gluing necessary.
Print with AT LEAST 30% infill and be careful removing supports, there are many fragile features.
DO NOT PRINT WITH A RAFT OR SUPPORT MATERIAL
as you can see in the images, part of my support material failed while printing because i bumped the printer, do not freak out of the supports fail mid print, they are mostly redundent and designed to recover.

there are TWO stl files included, PRINT THE 3DPrintReady FILE. I included files of the print without supports if you want to add your own supports. note a base is necessary or the model will tip over.

print this at .1mm layer height for optimal results.

i did a bunch of smoothing in Meshmixer, so the stl file is quite big even after being 'reduced' so be patient!

Im working on making the whole RWBY gang, but my job is sucking all my time and on top of that meshmixer keeps crashing so be patient! these things a pain to get printable

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Resolution:

.1 mm layer height

Infill:

30% this is critical that you make it at least 30 percent

Notes:

I printed this on a monoprice maker select plus (a rebrand of the wanhao, identical printer)
if you want to speed up print time, keep the outer layer slow, so it looks good, but increase the fill print speed.

IMPORTANT: you MUST have AT LEAST a .8mm shell thickness or the supports will fuse with the model! (need the model to be strong enough that when the supports are removed they dont take some of the model with them)

for scale, the model is ~139mm tall including base (5.48 in) i would strongly recommend not printing this any smaller, there are already very small and fragile features as it is. i can make a version with thicker supports so it can be printed smaller if requested, but it may take me some time to get to it.

just a pliers and a flush cut to remove any stringing and the break-away supports. be careful removing supports, the model has many detailed and thin features. especially with the hair.
cut the supports away for much better results.

this is a scan of an MMD model that posed and edited and made print ready with pmx editor and meshmixer. i also did a lot of smoothing, the scan had sharp polynomials and edges. The hair was a mess to fix, and lots of work in meshmixer was required. i spent a solid 9 hrs working on this model.
consider donating please, it really helps me stay motivated to keep spending the time to take pictures and post these :) thanks

The Viper model I worked off of was incredibly accurate, but it had many features that weren't print-friendly when scaled down to small build volumes (e.g. thin-sections, tiny details, etc.). For this model, I tried to stay as true to the Viper design as possible while creating a model that's easier and more durable to print in small build volumes. I like to think the changes are minor enough that they're unnoticeable unless you're comparing the models side by side, but they made a big difference for me in terms of printability.

description.text:
Wanted to use my monopod as a tripod when on long hiking trips rather than bring both as I use this as part of my tent. This uses a monopod that breaks down into three separate legs.

First I used a lighter on the flat extension areas and bent them to allow for a even placement, as each monopod section is a different length. Using a ball head I can further tune the "leveling".

I placed some Sugru(TM) in the leg holes and then wrapped the top of the "shafts" with plastic wrap to customize the fit.

Make sure you scale to 128% or 130% as conversion from Sketchup was not 100% accurate.

This is a set of bevel gears I designed to resemble the main gears of a differential. I liked to see the meshing action and decided to make the gears rotate smoothly using bearings left over from spinners.

This project requires 4 x 608zz bearings. (8mm ID x 22mm OD x 7mm H)

You need to insert the bearings in to each bevel gear all the way to the bottom. This will allow sufficient clearance between the gears to spin freely, without binding. Then just screw each bearing down to the cruciform.

To combine two of the finished Bevel Gear Fidgets together, print two extra screws and the "combiner". It's best to assemble the combiners and two cruciforms together with screws before adding the bevel gears.

Please post your makes!

print_settings.Notes:: Supports will probably help, but honestly shouldn't matter. Use 0.2mm layer height (or lower) but you will want to acetone/vapor polish  to make it (more) food safe. Do all this at your own risk, I take no responsibility, etc. Technically nothing can make it food safe, but smoothing out the lines should reduce the ability for bacteria to grow in the cracks. You could use a more food safe material like PET or nylon (And they might survive the dishwasher, unlike PLA) but they can't be easily polished. This part isn't intended to be washed anyways...

description.text:
Replacement ice "bucket" for my magic chef ice maker. Mine cracked and started leaking rusty water from the motor and the alternative is $35 here (http://www.appliancezone.com/mcim22ts-tw-02-magic-chef-ice-machine-bucket/
of 37 from amazon (https://www.amazon.com/Magic-Chef-MCIM22TS-TW-02-Bucket/dp/B01GTLXZ2S/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1504117340&sr=8-1&keywords=mcim22ts)

NO GUARANTEES THIS IS YOUR ACTUAL PART, FIND OUT YOUR MODEL NUMBER AND DO YOUR OWN RESEARCH!

This is pretty much the final design, but you may find the cut angle isn't quite right. I recommend printing it as two parts because it's just beyond a 200mm bed, but also because you can they adjust angle of the D-cut shaft. Just bolt on with a 40(?)mm m3 bolt, nut and locking washer, I would also use a 006/007 oring or rubber washer. If you are going to use the single piece version, I would verify the angle and let me know if it's off.

description.text: This is a simple square cookie-cutter generator. It allows to create single-frame cookie-cutters or cookie-cutters with an inner lower-profile cutter (to make a square imprint or cut in the middle of a square). The purpose of this object is to make square vols-au-vent (see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vol-au-vent) but it may be used to cut any other kind of pastry (btw, I make the cutter and my sweetheart will make the dish). The design has a top frame/grip to add some stiffness and a better handling to the cutter.

Customize variable and print. Has_Inner_Cutter:
yes - the cutter will have two frames, the inner one may be shorter than the outer to make an imprint instead of cutting a square hole.
no - the cutter will have one square frame. Cutter_Thickness: Specifies the thickness of the blade. I suggest a value slightly greater than or equal to your nozzle diameter. Outer_Side: Sets the size of the cutter.
Outer_Height: Sets the height of the cutter. Inner_Side_Difference: Specifies the space between the outer and inner cutters.
Inner_Height_Difference: Tells how shorter the inner cutter should be. If it's set to zero, both cutter will have the same height. Frame_Thickness: Sets the thickness of the cutter top frame. A thickness of 3mm makes the cutter reasonably stiff.
Frame_Flange: Adds extra width to the top frame to get a better grip.

I made this small shelf to hold most modern size cell phones, it hold my iPhone 6 in a lifeproof fre power case with a little room to spare. Screw holes are countersinked and sized to hold a standard course drywall screw flush with the plate. This ended up being incredibly sturdy, I printed it with a 15% infill, .2mm layers, with three layer top and bottom, and 2 layer sides, with PLA and i couldn't break or bend the shelf at all even putting almost my full weight on it. Probably a little overkill, but it does the job nicely.

I had no problems with the very long bridges required to print the lip on the top of the print, I did have to cut out a few strands of PLA that were a touch droopy but you can't see them once its mounted as it faces the wall.

Printed on a replicator 2 using inland PLA, and simplify 3D 3.0 as a slicer.

If your phone is larger than 3.5"x 6.5" feel free to modify the design to fit.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/crbw1xKemXt

I'm still working on this, the scale is approximately 1/72 but I know its not completely correct yet. I have not printed it yet either.

UPDATED 28 AUGUST:
Added 3 scaled separate .stl files (1/72, 1/76, 1/100) and one with all three scales. This is a war game model, the front bow around the ramp doesn't curve inward slightly and there are a few details that will be added later. I have not printed this yet but plan to this week, and I will post the result.

One thing to know if you try to print this model, I am trying a technique where the ramp moves up and down and is printed in with the hinges, There are posts at the top of the front to support the ramp in place when in the up position. title: M200 fan bracket with standoffs included (10mm or 15mm)

description.text:
Added standoffs to the excellent Thing - via TinkerCAD

TinkerCad URL's
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/euq0vNNKPMM-mpsm-fan-bed-with-15mm-legs
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fuXjM8w5bWa-mpsm-fan-bed-with-10mm-legs

Haven't installed it yet, still have the original in place - standoffs should fit between components, hopefully

1st draft was a mirror image of what I needed :o(

Update

Installed and working perfectly - plenty of space for the posts

If you are using the fan header on the motherboard you will need motion firmware v26 or above, as i understand its not enabled on earlier firmware. Also you may, I did, need to swap the wires over on the fan for it to work as they made a mistake when they wired the header. Before you swap any wires over though test you fan on the header that powers the head cooling fan. If you fan works there it will work on the motherboard fan header. If it doesn't swap the cables on your new fan in it's connector and retry it. Wires can be 'easily' pulled out of the connector. They have a small lip that stops them pulling out by accident. You need to gently push that in at the end nearest to the cable - ie away from the edge that connects to the motherboard

author: joshshutt

description.text:
This a case for MKS Wifi, a serial<->wifi module based on HLK-RM04, allowing some 3DPrinter controller board to be wireless.

This case have to support to mount it on a standard 2020 aluminum profile. It's design to largely protube from the 2020 profile, so that the antenna is free from obstacle.

It has a small hole for the antenna, and another one to access the reset button.

The top part may be a bit trickier to print than the bottom.

It uses standard M3x10 screws: 4 to close the box and fix the board at the same time, and 2 + T-nuts to fix it to the 2020 profile.

description.text:
Update 12-6-17
I totally rebuilt the extrusions in order to improve connection.. I added more tolerance on the connectors and the rod hole.. I hope this helps others be able to build this project..
I also added a ton of the parts needed to build the printer, as well as a bunch of extras..

I decided to put together a package of all the files you'll need to print an AM8 frame for the Anet A8. Since I've actually built one now, I'll update this info with me things I've learned during the build process..

The (x) before the file name is how many of each you'll need to print...

I also included the full length pieces if you happen to have access to a printer large enough to print them in 1 piece.

Join our Facebook group for help/support...
https://www.facebook.com/groups/1843740479205162/

Printer:

Anet A8

Yes

0.2-0.5

If you use at least 4 perimeters, the infill will automatically be 100% as it is really all walls, not infill....

title: Azteeg X1 lower side mount for prusa

description.text: This will allow you to mount your Azteeg X1 controller board on the lower side of your printer. Depending on how you orient it, it should be able to mount front or back, left or right and should also work to mount the azteeg under the bed rather than outside as it is pictured (I wanted mine on the outside to make it easier to adjust pololu stepper drivers).

Needed vitamins:
4x M3 15mm or longer (to mount azteeg)
3x M3 20mm or longer (to mount to prusa frame)
4x M3 washer
7x M3 nut The long bracket should attach to the bottom threaded rod that is used to mount the bottom of the Z axis. The two short brackets should clamp onto the bottom of a side triangle.

description.text: This tile set has been superseded by the much improved OpenForge 2.0 Tudor set. That set is both more complete, and vastly better designed, please, check it out.

Tudor style wall tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github

• Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.

9/27/2014 - Found a new way to do wood that results in better/simpler models. Regenerated using that technique.
10/15/2016 - Deprecated OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

Printed in black. Dry brushed with dark brown and then used ever lighter shades in the dry brush. To lighten, used a light leather, not a white in order to get more yellow in the highlights.
The walls were painted in white, then mixed with the leather color, finally I stippled the walls with white again using a toothbrush.

description.text: The Vulture Droid, highly nimble, and able to function both in flight and on land, this CIS ship flies on a small base.

Work in progress.

This is a mounting kit for a Thinkware F50 Dashcam. I did not like the permanent 3M stick mounts and wanted to use a suction cup mount. I have had good experiences with RAM mounts, so this is a direct fit kit for the 1" Ball mount. The FreeCAD models have also been uploaded. The model could be modified to be threaded without inserts, but I don't know if threading directly into the plastic will provide enough tension without stripping. This is why I used the heat-set inserts. Stainless fasteners are not required, that is just what I had on hand from another project that needed stainless. Any M3x0.5mm threaded fastener would work. I am currently trying to source a thumb screw so that I don't need an allen wrench to adjust the mount. I printed the first prototype in PLA, so I will update on how it handles the sun over time. I will upload pictures later.

Parts I used:

  • 1" RAM mount
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008JGZMZK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

  • M3 Allen Screws -> McMaster Part No. 92095A185
    https://www.mcmaster.com/#92095a185/=194rwwe

author: SM264

title: Bullet feeder - complete and fully customizable
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Fully customizable bullet feeder. Collator plate can easily be adjusted to fit your needs (see "COLLATOR PLATE GENERATOR" below). Nose down conversion also available.

The dimensions for the base plate are:
173.0 x 155.7 x 90.0 mm (6.81 x 6.10 x 3.54 inches)

PROOF OF CONCEPT VIDEO NOSE DOWN CONVERSION

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9iTjlmzJLz0 (by AmmoMike83)

Videos of working bullet feeder

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gKWYAgOTz58 (by tekhobbycap)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EO8HuW9l8MQ (by Lordneeoo)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c85oUROW054 (by AmmoMike83)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Dol5EOtG-M (by Konni68)

Video of working light barrier auto stop

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sH80AcEvQGM (by AmmoMike83)

Additional/needed parts
  • Springs: https://www.doublealpha.biz/mrbulletfeeder-output-spring-and-extension-adaptor „Two sizes are available. The Small (10mm inner diameter) matches the springs used with the rifle caliber machines and the large size (12mm inner diameter) as shipped with the pistol calibers.”
  • Motor: https://www.doublealpha.biz/de/mr-bulletfeeder-motor
  • Controller: https://www.amazon.com/Pixnor-Controller-Adjustable-Reversible-reversing/dp/B01H1W79S0/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1518027523&sr=8-5&keywords=12v+controller
  • Light barrier controller: https://www.conrad.de/de/kemo-lichtschranke-b045-bausatz-191413.html
A lot of very useful 3D printable parts for the bullet feeder. I really appreciate it! Thank you tekhobbycap!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2772454

COLLATOR PLATE GENERATOR

INSTRUCTIONS

  • download openSCAD (http://www.openscad.org/downloads.html)
  • download collator plate generator (https://www.thingiverse.com/download:4637826)
  • open generator with openSCAD
  • modify options
  • press F5 for preview
  • press F6 to render
  • FILE / EXPORT / STL EXPORT
  • save your STL file
  • print
  • reload
  • shoot
UPDATES

UPDATE 2018/02/23

  • added working video of nose down conversion
  • changed the collator plates of the pistol calibers to 13mm height
  • added a solid nose down ATP. You can mill it down as you like it. :)
  • added a solid ATP.

  • addded another nose down ATP with a more flattened angle

UPDATE 2018/02/12

UPDATE 2018/02/11

  • added dillon rod mount (by derollmann) - (Picture: https://cdn.thingiverse.com/renders/7e/23/8e/10/b0/2313ec4600a5c11cd822fa73ed57996f_preview_featured.jpg)

UPDATE 2018/02/07

  • new nose down conversion kit with a spring housing
    -- https://www.thingiverse.com/download:4657982 (ATP)

comments.text: Here is the 6mm Motor Anchor I made that may help someone out. This anchor merely guides the bullet plate, a steel rod handles drive shaft torque. I have two DC motors and the shafts (the key detail) is quite different between them; where the key starts on the drive shaft and how deep. This printed a few percent loose on both shafts and a few percent tight on the bullet plate so some fitting is required. I used the shaft of a 1.98mm drill that broke, 28mm long.

title: Mk IV Bad Cat Sliding Door Latch

description.text:
After waking up a few times to discover that the cat had opened the back door and let himself out of the house. I took a video if you want to see him let the dog/cats out.
We decided something needed to be done, so this is the...

Mark IV Bad Cat Door Latch!

This probably wouldn't stop even a more determined human, but it has been improved over the v3 latch. A human did break the v3 latch, and, though it was glued, the cat was also then able to destroy the latch and leave the house :(

  • Stronger latch so that it won't break as easily
  • Stronger mount for the same reason!
  • Bigger diameter hole for the screw (it was tight enough it cracked one of mine)
  • It stays in the "unlocked" position more reliably! (Don't lock yourself out!)
  • When open, if it falls down, it stays horizontal.
  • and it has a slope so that it'll climb over the door handle without help
  • Improved cat-proof-i-ness

Obviously, this is intended to fit my Pella sliding door handle, however other folks may have handles that can work with simple modification. Sketchup file is attached.

It needs 3 screws. 2 wood screws (or metal) to attach to the door frame, and one to act as a pin between the "hook" and "mount" parts.

As you can see in the photo, my cat's mechanically inclined, always trying to figure out how things work. This may not stop him for long, but so far it's been a huge help!

Video of the Bad Cat (door latch): https://youtu.be/goiY7Q03bSY
And the actual Bad Cat (himself): https://youtu.be/aBWv2REA68c

Notes
  • I printed with a 25% infill in ABS figuring that I didn't want the cat to rip it apart. It's pretty strong.
  • Printed on its side this time. That requires some small bit of support in the middle, however that means the layers are in the direction of the forces trying to pull it apart, so it should be much stronger. The previous one's mount failed on layer separation when the cat got determined enough.
  • I used a 1 inch #8 screw for the "pin" - the hole is tight, I had to fuss a bit to get the threads of the screw to bite in my ABS print.
  • Clearly the mount screws need to be appropriately sized for the holes and type of door frame (wood/metal/whatever) you're using.
  • It should be reasonably easy to stretch or shorten the arm or the clasp part if need be.
  • If you adjust it, use care with the hinge location. You want the clasp bit to remain leaning back when "open" so that you don't lock yourself out.

History

You can look at the "remixed from" for previous versions. That makes it obvious where we reinforced bits so that it might be stronger. I left the old versions up for their educational value - here's how I could improve those old versions....

description.text:
This was designed to be printed in TPU/ninjaflex/etc, it will not work with non-flexible filaments. All the ports, speakers, etc. should not be blocked by the phone case as long as you have your support settings dialed in reasonably well. This phone case costs about $1.50 (USD) in hatchbox TPU filament.

The back of the phone case is made flat in order to make this easier and quicker to print, and the square holes are to help make the back of the case easier to grip.

The rectangular cutout on the inside is for holding those thin steel plates that come with magnetic phone mounts. I made it 59.5x41.5x0.5mm since that's what I needed.

Printer:

Vulcanus V1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

<0.3

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

Print with the flat portion facing the bed.

Support settings you need to use (S3D):
Horizontal Offset From Part = 1.30mm
Upper Vertical Separation Layers = at least 1
Lower Vertical Separation Layers = at least 1
Support Pillar Resolution = 1.00mm
Max Overhang Angle = 15deg for Hatchbox TPU

For support infill percentage I used 20%

The bumps on the sides of the case and the buttons should not have supports under them.
Trim drooped lines & support material with flush cutters.

description.text:
https://youtu.be/TtVIgmclNN0

I made this project to use on my Grabber i3.

Part of the project was to create a way to easily replace differents toolheads on my 3D printer, because I want to create new tools in the future.

The original mount of my extruder was made with 2 pieces of mdf, holding the linear guides as a sandwich, and the extruder bolts pass through one of this pieces and is locked with a nut by inside, what make this really tricky to unmount, so I leave on this project the SLT file to the tool holder that I create to my 3D printer, I locked this piece on my original X axis and put a m3 nut inside, so if I wanted to change the toolhead the only thing that I need is to unscrew a tool and put the new one.

To the pen holder you will need to use a elastic, this will act as a spring holding the pen against the paper.

Essa peça foi feita para minha uma Grabber i3, precisa de adaptação para outros modelos.

A ideia desse projeto foi inicialmente permitir múltiplas ferramentas para a impressora 3d, permitindo trocar a extrusora por outra peça sem muita dificuldade, e comecei por esse suporte para caneta.

O projeto é composto por 3 peças o corpo que vai preso no eixo X, uma pequena chapa que passa por dentro do corpo e onde vão parafusados 2 prendedores onde será fixada a caneta, assim a peça permite que a caneta se movimente livremente na vertical, os 2 pequenos ganchos foram feitos para permitir a entrada de um elástico, ele serve como uma mola segurando a caneta contra o papel durante a impressão, isso garante que a caneta não se afasta caso a mesa esteja levemente inclinada.

A parameterized spool holder that should plug onto the sides of a table. I'm not thoroughly convinced of its durability but we'll see. This has pretty much just been a way for me to learn a bit of openscad.

Remember to tweak the parameters according to your need:
tableThickness: Thickness of your desk
tableDepth: How deep you want the cylinder that grips the desk
spoolLength: How long the spool holder is
spoolRadius = How thick the spool holder is
spoolRimRadius = Radius of the rim that gets added to the spool radius

Other variables should be obvious.
ok

Make your friend happy by giving him this cute Minion. The Minion is hollow inside, so you can put a gif on it. This also works as a storage box for example for earrings and rings.

On 1:1 scale, minion is ~12cm height, but you can scale this up to 2:1 and it can be printed on the most printers.

You can choose on STL files, whether to print Minion from two or four parts. The minion made of the four parts, of course, requires a little more finishing, but one part of Minion can print an example even after work. All parts need supports.

My Minion is printed at four parts. After printing just glue parts together and do finishingwork.

Spend some time to making finishingwork and make accurate and detailed paintwork. I know, it's sometimes very frustrating, but at the end you will get your price. ;)

I'm very interested to see your printed and finished Minion, so please post picture of your finished Minion.

description.text:
If you join midpoints of an object, it creates a 2nd object, and if you join the midpoints of the 2nd objects it creates the original 1st object., This model is to illustrate that idea to help kids understand it.
Midpoint Polygon Conjecture: For every simple polygon there exists a smallest natural number k such that after k iterations of midpoint polygon procedure, we obtain a convex polygon.

Printer:

Dremel Idea builder

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes:

Takes about 3 hours each to print

Introduction Midpoint Polygon Procedure: Given a n-sided simple polygon, join the consecutive midpoints of the sides to generate another n-sided simple polygon.
Midpoint Polygon Conjecture: For every simple polygon there exists a smallest natural number k such that after k iterations of midpoint polygon procedure, we obtain a convex polygon.
Read more at: https://gaurish4math.wordpress.com/2017/04/02/midpoint-polygon-conjecture/

Preview shows some nasty connecting points but the 3D view is OK. And of course the stl could be sliced and printed without problems as you can see on pictures.

author: DrBigLove

description.text: This snaps on and fits quite tight! Made for my gearbest E3D V6 clone, but should also fit originals! Very aerodynamic and sleek, this should fit and flow exceedingly well. Made for a 40mm fan. The V6 heatsink shaft diameter is 22.27mm and the V6 heatsink height is 26.15mm. A bit of refining went into the inside to optimize flow and onto the outside to match aesthetically. One version stands alone and the other has mounts for print cooling fans. The mounts have a 3mm hole and will fit a 4mm wide cylinder with a 6mm diameter and 1mm fillets. Everything is supposed to be tight and not move once it's in its desired location. Use the standard compressor turbines to optimize flow for the heatsink, and use the High Compression turbines for the "Twin Tornado" print cooling fans.
A thin pyrolytic graphite sheet floats above a powerful neodymium magnets. It has covered with an acrylic dome (half of 6 cm Christmas ball).
Neodymium cube magnet levitates between diamagnetic bismuth puck.

title: CV joints for tahustvedt's Ursa (bear) - Fully printable Monster Truck

description.text:
Made these for tahustvedt's Ursa (bear) - Fully printable Monster Truck https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2299884 to try and make a long lasting printable CV joint for diff's

Seem to handle testing so far, ended with the one of the diff gears blowing up. Steering lock to lock is easier and less drag.

I used 1.75 filament for the pin and it seems to be ok, did plan to use a 2mm metal pin.

Can be replaced with out splitting the diff.

9-7-17
Added the parts to change the drive shafts from Gearbox to diffs
New axles for the diffs with better centering of the balls for cv's (0.8mm longer) and 0.3mm more clearance for the spider gears (bearing 0.3mm closer on long axle) as i found mine to tight on the side gears with the new 4 spider diff.

9-7-17
New diff input gear. might be easier to
assemble and stronger.

11-10-17
New ball ends, V2 longer and radius in the bottom of the groove.

12/5/17
Updated to latest versions
Using tig welding wire 1.8mm for the pins

Sanding of the top surface (the only visible surface when the holder is placed in the guitar).

The original extruder mount was simple but requires zip tie to secure them on to the metal frame. Doing maintenance on these extruder requires us to cut the zip ties and waste even more of the zip ties.

This is to eliminate the need of zip ties and those extruders can be cleaned easily.

There are cases that my extruder grind the filament and they needed to be cleaned.

"lock.stl" are optional but recommended so these extruder won't fall off accidentally since there are nothing locking he mount in place

Additional Notes

New "lock.st" has been uploaded and replaced the old one. This is due to the old one are being too thick and when the z axis is at 190, the x carriage will hit with this lock. The newer one has been adjusted for this clearance.

Remove the lock if you're planning to print up to 200mm tall as the cable will get caught with the lock object at around 195mm and above

Customizable base for 28mm miniatures, tailored for printable minis here on Thingiverse that don't come with their own bases.

Comes in round, square, and hex variations as well as numbered sets with 1-n embossed on the surface of the base for easy DM book-keeping during large battles with lots of duplicate minis.

Included SCAD file allows control over sizes, the creation of slotted bases as well as double-length bases for weird long minis, and the ability to place textures on top of each base from heigh map image files.

The default bevel used by these bases is designed to make picking them up from a table easy, even if they're being used as tokens without figures, but some folks prefer other options… If you create your own variant in Customizer, you can also hand-draw a custom bevel profile.

print_settings.Notes:: Supports are required. Use whatever resolution you prefer. Infill can also be adjusted to your preference. I've printed mine with PLA+.

My bob's big boy.
You have the option of what to put
on the tray.
I provide an empty tray.
A burger, and the head of
Ronald McDonnald
or you can make your own tray item.

Print the boy, and the tray.
glue tray to his hand.
print what you want him to carry
put said thing on the tray.
He really looks best painted
He will stand with the tray and ronald's head,
but it is not super steady.
either make a base (you can make a second tray)
or put magnets on the feet (like i do with most of my figures)
these are a good price for their strength
http://www.harborfreight.com/10-piece-rare-earth-magnets-67488.html
with these on his feet he is super steady!!! if you scale big boy take note of the scaling factor when scaling the tray. The Ronald head is my joke (for a friend).
(Bring me the head of Ronald McDonald)
you can make the big boy hold a tray with
whatever you see fit. a burger is privided for that "authentic" look
I think you might want to scale the burger down a bit, it's
really big as it is.

author: fabricatingadventures

description.text:
Peristaltic pump extruder for 3DRAG printer.

The pump is optimized for a silicone tube of 3.5 mm diameter. The tube diameter can be changed in the parametric openScad files. The extruder is provided with a tube suitable for standard deliverable pipette tips. Please note that an O-ring is inserted in between the two printed parts (named ..ugello...) to avoid leakages.
Three 100 ohm resistors are placed in series instead of the thermistor in order to let software read a temperature of about 200 °C.
No special settings are necessary in the slicer, only changing the diameter of the filament (trial and errors) and the nozzle diameter (i.e. the hole of pipette tip) are needed for the configuration.
If the motor rotates in the wrong direction simply invert two wires.
The extruder is able to draw easily alginates solution 4 wt %. In the movie the alginate solution stained with a die is pipetted inside a calcium chloride solution in order to start the gelification.

This project was designed for a thesis project of Adelia De Santo (RadChemLab, university of Pavia (IT))

https://youtu.be/e5Y5iUAPeoo

This simple but effective mod allows you to fit a Walkera G2D gimbal to the stock camera mount fitting beneath the battery.
Allows for quick and easy fitting and removal of the gimbal.
I used this clip to secure my Akaso EK700 camera .... https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795933
And this is the landing gear I use ..... https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B06VV21JYF/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
I had to drill the landing gear screw holes a bit wider as they didn't quite line up with the Bugs 3.
First test with the gimbal fitted ..... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FKtRV4nx8h4&feature=youtu.be

Gimbal mount adapter :

Fix the adapter to the gimbal mounting plate with 2 screws and nuts (see pictures above).

Gimbal power :

I used the balance port from the stock battery to power the gimbal.
Remove the female connector and middle wire from a 2s lipo balance expansion cable and splice it to the cable with the 2 pin female connector that comes with the gimbal.
(Make sure to splice the red wire to red and black to black)
This is the cable I used ..... http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Lipo-Balance-Extension-Charger-Cable-Lead-2s-JST-XH-2-cell-7-4V/230786425855?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

print_settings.Notes:: It's a big piece. I use 0,8mm nozzle and 0.2mm or 0.3mm layer height.

description.text:
(en castellano más abajo)

Structure for a 4 litophane lamp.

It's designed for 4 96x96x3mm litophanes. You can generate the litophanes using http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ or any software (cura will do it fine)

I use Cura for printing litophanes. Just drop your jpg file and set a 0,3mm base, 2,7mm height and "darker is higher". Print at 0.1mm layer height and 100% infill.

I usually preprocess the pictures (delete or soften the background, increase contrast, convert to B&W) and draw a 3mm black frame around the photo to get a thick border in the litophane, so I get a 90x90 picture with 3mm frame around -> 96x96mm litophane.

For lighting I use a 1w led, or a 50cm led strip.

Link for the switch: http://www.ebay.es/itm/252518482179

(SPANISH:)

Estructura para una lámpara con 4 litofanías.

Está diseñada para cuatro litofanías de 96x96x3mm. Puedes generarlas usando http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ o cualquier software (cura lo hace bien)

Yo uso Cura para hacer las litofanías. Simplemente abrir una imagen jpg, y configurar con 2.7mm de altura, 0.3mm de base y seleccionar "darker is higher". Imprimir a 0.1mm de altura de capa y 100% de relleno.

Normalmente preproceso las fotos (borrar o difuminar el fondo, subir contrastes, pasar a blanco y negro) y le dibujo un marco de 3mm alrededor de la foto de 90x90mm, con lo que quedaría una foto de 96x96mm. El marco negro en la litofanía quedará como un marco grueso, dando rigidez a la foto.

Para iluminar uso un led de 1w o una tira de leds de 50cm. OJO: No usar nada que se pueda calentar mucho.

La tapa tiene un hueco para el interruptor: http://www.ebay.es/itm/252518482179

comments.text: Hi, nice idea to add the depth markers on the sides.
comments.author: Bixx

comments.text:
Thanks, I have tried and for most jobs does not exceed the limit, for this reason I added the level markers, this way you can have a clear reference of how far to fill.
If you reach the limit you think that you will almost also overflow the vat, so that it also serves as a security system allowing the inner container to be filled before the resin overflows outside the vat.

description.text:
Hi there! I created this laptop stand with the simple desire to play music from my laptop without cluttering my desk for other things.

I worked out that most laptops will still function when the lid is shut at about 5-10 degrees. Using this I designed a vertical stand which would be able to safely store my MacBook Pro vertically whilst allowing it to continue operating.

This also applies to those times you wish to connect your laptop to a monitor/tv via HDMI and wish to minimise the space taken up by the laptop.

title: BEEHIVE, Planche d'envole pour plateau NICOT.Board of flight for plateau

description.text:
Plateforme pour plancher NICOT
Très bonne tenue sur le plateau.
Mise en place par emboîtement les deux plots biseautés, sous la planche et pivotement du bloc.
Deux plaques d'envol par plateau.

NICOT floor platform
Very good performance on the set.
Installation by interlocking the two bevels, under the board and pivoting block.
Two flight plates per tray.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm Buse 0.4 mm

Notes:

Bonjour,

En PLA , avec une couche de peinture.( en ABS tenue du plateau critique)
Épaisseur de recouvrement 1 %
Réglage remplissage à 12 %

Pour la mise en place :
Il est préférable de faire un essai sur un plateau Nicot vide.
Les deux blocs de fixation doivent bien être inclinés, sur le plateau, pour l’emboîtement.
Il faut emboîter un coté puis l'autre et non les deux en même temps.
Il force un peu au début c'est normal pour une bonne tenue sur le plateau.
Mais doit se glisser sur le plateau voir photo ...
Les plateaux sont posés sur mes 10 ruches sans soucis.

Si vous voulez un renseignement ne pas hésiter à me laisser un message.

Hello,

In PLA, with a layer of paint (in ABS held the critical plateau)
Coverage thickness 1%
12% fill setting

For setting up:
It is best to give a test on an empty Nicot tray.
The two fixing blocks must be inclined, on the plate, for the interlocking.
We must fit one side then the other and not both at the same time.
It forces a little at first it's normal for a good performance on the board.
But must slip on the plateau see photo ...
The trays are placed on my 10 hives without worries.

If you want an information do not hesitate to leave me a message.

author: nuggyblake

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3L9skbPc2Nn

Will fit 11mm thumb nut. Add a dab of superglue at the bottom for good measure.
Print one by one or 4 at once.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

25%

Wire. You head out, pick up 80m of assorted hookup in fancy colours to make a keyboard.. and it ends up in piles.. but no more! Why not just print out a spool? And since i can make it a custom object, might as well add a few extra features that I always want. In brief:

  • each spool is sized for roughly 25m of AWG25 hookup (my hookup has an OD of about 2mm for reference), which is about the most i'm ever likely to want to have floating around.

  • all the cutouts are 2.2mm nominal so you can thread the wire through it to hold things down neatly,

  • those long cuts should give you an at-a-glance side view of how much you have left

  • since they're 2.2 nom, you can also stack your spools on top of each other, just put your loose end through one of the small holes, and then whatever you shove on top? align the wire through the hole and you're good.

  • there are five core-holes, so if you wanted to you could spool 2-3 or so different wires on the one. Would suggest printing more, but that's just me.

Printing and assembly

The part is done up as a simple object that's mirrored - print as many half spools as you need and join together. Note! Those center pegs are for alignment ONLY. Unless you want to print at 100%, they will snap off. You will want to apply a glue to fasten it all together and fill those voids

I would say just do the thing at 20% fill and 0.2mm layer height and be done with it - it's a utility piece.

Notes:

Note that my wall thickness; all round, is set to 1.2mm thick. Printed in standard off the shelf ABS. You will need 2 identical pieces to form the bracket, don't say I never stated.

Model is set in optimal printing orientation and designed for printing in either PLA or ABS, or any material you deem fit; Ultem and carbon-fibre will be overkill.

For durable and long lasting spool support, I used grey PVC pipes; commonly used for high-pressure water delivery. OD 26mm, ID 20mm

Why it is so blocky, with so many angles.

The model was drawn in Sketchup, and areas that would not close due to mesh problem; those using SketchUp should know what I mean, was fixed in Microsoft's 3D Builder app.

The pins and layout were adapted from Kitchen Paper Roll Holder for Ikea IVAR by krizzli.

The model was designed to be durable over aesthetic looks; because spools falling on my machine is a must-never situation for me.

author: farnix

description.text:
This is a pen plotter capable of printing on A4 paper sheets. It is intended to be similar to the Aritma Amagraph pen plotter, be as compact and robust as posible as well as reliable.
It is controlled by means of an arduino with a grbl shield, wich drives the x and y motors, and the solenoid used for lifting-lowering the pen in response to g-code generated in inkscape and sent through grbl controller. Scroll down for a gif of it working, bill of materials, instructions...

Whatch a video here: https://juanggengineering.blogspot.ca/2018/01/a4-pen-plotter.html

Printer:

P3 Steel

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

20%

Depending on your printer, some holes may be drilled to make bolts fit. Big tolerances are used, so no sanding is required.

Here you have a gif of it working. (It is actually a lot smoother)

First, the overall idea was drawn on paper. Then, it was designed on the computer using FreeCAD, and after four versions and some trial and error, the final design was completed.Some features were added after the build like some holes for wiring and so on.

1) 3d printed parts (All files starting with "Print"):

Print one of each (ending in x1) or two (ending in x2). One needs to be mirrored as specified in its name.

2) Non 3d printed parts:

a)Metal profiles:
Stls included for dimensions. Material specified in their name.
In addition, two 6mm ID 30 mm long 0,5 mm thickness brass tubes are needed to act as
bearings between x carriage and the steel shafts.

b)Screws (and their nuts):
1 M4x20 mm
1 M4x40 mm
15 M3x12 mm
4 M3x30 mm
10 M2,5x8mm
8 2x10 wood screws
2 M4 wing nuts (optional)

c)Electronics:
1 Arduino UNO
1 arduino CNC shield (with drivers)
Mosfet circuit to drive the solenoid using the spindle pin(example included)
1 Enstop
1Power switch
1 Jack conector
1Red LED
1 470 Ohm resistor
Asorted wires
USB cable
A computer to generate and send the g-code to the plotter.

d) Actuators:
2 NEMA 17 x 35 mm stepper motors.
1 Spring loaded 12v solenoid (mine was from an old printer, use the one you have and glue
it in place.

e) Misc:
Paper rollers from an old printer (you can print them yourself)
Sand paper to glue on the 12mm alumninum tube to grip the paper
4 Ball bearings 4mmID 13mmOD 5mm thickness
Heatsrink tubing
Cable ties
6mm wide Belt and pulley
6 x 12 mm spring

And the compulsory one: Some free time.

1) Mechanical assembly:

Follow the photographs, drawings, and the assembly reference step file, it should be pretty obvious where everything goes.
Some hints:

  • Captive nuts that hold everything toguether are located on the inside of the holes where the profiles go (there is an hexagonal slot in which they fit), insert them and engage the screw BEFORE putting the profile in.

  • The 12 mm OD aluminum tube is fixed to the motor shaft in one end and to an M4 screw on the other end by means of three M 2.5 x 8 mm screws in a triangle arrangement (see photo gallery), with the nuts inside, so they press on the shaft. This allows to center it precisely. If you find it too complicated, you can always use lots of tape, but that its not very professional, neither reliable.

  • X motor screw holes are a bit enlarged to adjust belt tension.

  • There is one spring in the moving carriage that presses the pen against tha paper. This spring is kept in place between two small circular slots. The solenoid spring must overcome this spring force in order to push the lever up.

  • Sandpaper is wraped in a spiral way around the 12 mm OD tube in order to grip the paper. You can glue this with contact glue or similar.

Don't hesitate to ask any questions, and sorry for not providing step-by-step guide with photographs. I am not able to do that at the moment.

2) Electrical assembly

  • I assume I don't have to provide an schematic for the main power switch and LED.

  • The tricky part is the solenoid driving circuit. While you can use the schematic provided with a P-chanel MOSFET, I encourage you to use an N-chanel MOSFET so you can get rid of the transistor. Look for schematics online.

  • I added an LED to check whether the solenoid is powered or not and some buttons (Pause, continue, reset, e-stop) These are not necesary for it to work, but they come in handy.
3) Loading and configuring grbl
  • Download grbl here: https://github.com/grbl/grbl
  • Configuration instructions: https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Grbl-v1.1-Configuration
  • Scroll down for the settings I used. (Steps per mm may vary in your machine, just print some squares and keep adjusting until you get it right)
4.1) G-code generation (Vector files)

  • Use this for lineal drawings, or with dxf, svg...files.

  • You can convert bitmaps to vector on inkscape on path > trace bitmap.

  • To generate g-code, I used inkscape and jtech photonics laser tool (https://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=2012).

  • This plug in needs some modifications in order to work for our needs:

    Go to C:\Program Files (x86)\Inkscape\share\extensions\laser.py, open it with your
    favourite text edditor (I used notepad ++) and make sure the following three lines look like
    in the photo below:

This will allow us to use custom g-code to turn the laser(in our case the solenoid) on and off.
Otherwise it will add laser power and more stuff. This way it worked for me.
I used the spindle enable pin on the cnc shield (m8 on, pen down, m9 off, pen up), but you can use the coolant pin as well.

4.2) G-code generation (Bitmaps)

  • Use this to print images like the submarine photo you can see above. Keep in mid that this will take much longer, depending on the resolution used.

  • For this, I used another plug-in for inkscape:
    https://github.com/305engineering/Inkscape
    This needs no modifications.
5) G-code sending
  • I used grbl controller (https://github.com/zapmaker/GrblHoming/releases)
  • This program will also let you configure grbl once it is loaded.

comments.text: Cool design!  I wonder if someone could add a more precise Y axis control, which would allow for varying thickness/darkness of lines with some media (like pencil or even a paint brush).  Is it possible with vector images to encode a "thickness" parameter along a spline path?
comments.author: natevplas

comments.text:
You mean Z axis? You can easily add a servo motor to control the pressure, but programming it is more of a challenge. What you can do is generate g-code for each thickness in the drawing and use a different range of movement of the servo motor to achieve different pressure and thus thickness. Then add all the g.code in a single file. Or you can always change the pen in between.
Tell me if you achieve something. Good luck.
comments.author: natevplas

comments.text: Yes, I guess I meant Z!  I'm used to 3D animation/modeling where Y is up and XZ is the horizontal plane.  I'm imagining something similar to a Wacom tablet with pressure sensitivity.  So a line can start out one thickness, then get thicker and thinner over the length of the line to create more of a hand-drawn look.  This is way beyond my ability, but just wanted to throw it out there hoping to inspire someone with the know-how.
comments.author: JuanGg

comments.text: I see. On inkscape, when you convert a bitmap to SVG or with a vector file with thickness, it takes the outline. If you are lucky, you can get some range of thickness based on how spaced those lines are.

comments.text:
Could you please give more details of the solenoid? Basic dimensions would be useful, whether it's a 'push' or 'pull' solenoid, and what the armature throw is. Then I can search ebay for something similar!
Many thanks.
comments.author: David_J

comments.text:
I got this solenoid from an old laser printer, so I cannot provide details on how to get it. Its aproximate dimensions are 26 x 20 x 30 mm. You can try to glue yours in place, or drill some holes and screw it in place.
In my setup (which is not the most reliable), the solenoid is a pull one, with spring return. When the solenoid is activated, the carriage's spring presses the pen against the paper. When the solenoid is released, solenoid's spring pushes a lever up, with in turn lifts the pen, overcoming the carriage's spring force. It works for me, but could be improved.
If you use 'liquid ink' pens (wich don't need to be pressed much against the paper to write as bic pens do) you can get rid of the carriage spring and use a much weaker solenoid.
Good luck with your build!

comments.text:
Currently this is the most compact and elegant plotter here on thingiverse.
This would be the first time I use a selenoid and I would need to get one from ebay or amazon. There are 5V selenoids available. I guess those would work aswell and I could skip the MOSFET?
comments.author: punkrockseb

comments.text:
Thank you!
Even with using a 5V solenoid, you won't skip the MOSFET, becouse they draw quite a few current (they have current 'peaks' at start).
And you will need a more powerful 5 v power supply than the arduino regulator. As the motors run at 12v, a same voltage solenoid is preferred.
Depending on the solenoid, you could even use a transistor. Don't be afraid of using mosfets, just do some research before (There are plenty of schematics on the internet) and if you use an N-Chanel MOSFET, you can drive it without a transistor. (I used a P-Chanel MOSFET becouse it was what I happened to have around) Don´t forget the diode, or you will fry your MOSFET.
Also I found usefull adding a led, so I could see when the solenoid was activated.
comments.author: punkrockseb

just start bilding this ploter. and will make it better. all those rods are difrent in diametar. why? and will pen up/down proces connect to servo motor, instead this solenoid. and will switch all motor to one side, so next project will make bigger/longer ploter easy proces.

comments.author: spiro

comments.text: I don't know which rods are you talking about. They have the dimendions they have becouse that was what I happened to have around. Everything is like it is for a reason, a servo may seem easier to control (it is not, really, a solenoid can be driven using the spindle enable on pretty much any version of grbl) but will be much slower in operation and wear out much faster. Stepers are placed on different sides for space isues and to allow more air to flow around them, not concentrating heat on one spot (they do get hot, even in this light duty aplication). Having said that, I encourage you to make any changes you wish, and please make sure you publish them.
