description.text:
A simple 3d printed frame for a 16x16 1s build.

I'm using the pepperf1sh FC with built in Frsky receiver and 4 in 1 esc and a 600mAh 1s battery. Motors are Racerstar 1103 8000kv, and props are 2435 60mm 4 blade racerstar props. Not a ton of power, but I get about 3 minutes FPV flight and is super quiet.
Adapts 2" caster to Grid Beam standard. Grid beam uses 1/4-20 hardware to join 2x2s together, this adapter makes a 2" caster compatible with this system.

• Measure your caster to see if it's the same size as mine.
  • Adjust settings within the SCAD file.
  • Print.
  • Assemble. I use a 2.5" long 1/4-20 bolt, as 2" is just too short.
  • Make moveable Grid Beam objects.
    • I ended up using M3 bolts to join to my caster, as my measurements were a little off.

Twist to lock in place.  It snaps to the vertical position and stays locked in.  
Overkill for cable management and the same task could be accomplished with a flat piece with two holes, I know.  But where's the fun in that?
This is an adapter that fits to a PC 80mm fan, and fits an 80mm downpipe (or similar) to join to it

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this in PETG but would expect that it would also be fine in ABS, PLA or anything else you may wish as the power supply does not get that hot. This can be printed on the A8 but I found it best to print diagonally to get the best use of the heat bed, also it does not mayyer which side you print on they both have 3 count bores.

description.text:
Recently my original 20A 12V supply for my Anet A8 died, so I upgraded to a spare 30A PSU I had earmarked for another project. However the mounting holes were completely different, so I designed this simple adaptor plate.

Th PSU that I used is an unnamed brand from what I can find but has a model number S-360-12. If you google this number you can find them pretty cheap, mine was from Ebay and cost around £16.

Printer:

Aney A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this in PETG but would expect that it would also be fine in ABS, PLA or anything else you may wish as the power supply does not get that hot. This can be printed on the A8 but I found it best to print diagonally to get the best use of the heat bed, also it does not mayyer which side you print on they both have 3 count bores.

Parts Used

Here are the parts I used;

  • 3 x M3 x 16mm machine screw
  • 3 x M3 x 5mm machine screw
  • 3 x M3 nuts (self locking)
Putting Fitting It

Place the 16mm machine screws into the three holes that create the smallest triangle, make sure that the head are in the counterbored side as below. You can add a bit of hot glue to hold the screws in place if you wish i didn't bother but may have made tightening a tad easier.

Adding the screws

Carefully turn this over so the screws stick out and place onto the power supply, line up the holes and using the three smaller screws fit the adaptor trapping the longer screws in place. Be careful not to overtighten, some of these chinese PSUs have the screws bottom out on the PCB inside, that is why these screws are so short for this design.

Adaptor fitted to PSU

Finally line up the screw holes, the holes I used are the ones that held the PSU in originally so there should be no issues with placement. Fit the nuts on the other side, i used ones that I had spares of from my kit, but Nylocs or a double standard nut would work to lock the part in place. To tighten them properly I used a pair of pliers to hold the thread and a spanner for the nut, if you used hot glue this would not have been an issue.

PSU fitted!

title: Skewered Trilobite Hair Clip (small, simplified, plated)

description.text: I'm proud to introduce what is perhaps the most sophisticated and stylish fashion accessory ever produced by humanity -- the Skewered Trilobite Hair Clip. It goes equally well with a wedding gown, a Princess Leia costume, or even as an accessory in your act as a hair metal band, because trilobites are timeless and noble (not to mention "something old"). It's the perfect hair accessory to keep your buns aligned. I know many of you will ask, "Why skewer this poor little creature?" The answer is simple if you've ever tried them grilled with rum butter glaze. Now you can go from refined and chic to laid-back and slaked when you reach back to dramatically produce this extinct marine anthropod from your bushy locks -- just in time for desert. Please post photos of this being worn at fancy galas and receptions -- in particular those hosted by heads of state, movie stars, and famous paleontologists. Breaking news: Also great on bushy beards! And please be careful -- this is high fashion, and thus with it comes a great deal of peril and responsibility. Features of This Variation

This thing takes AuntDaisy's exceptional Trilobite articulatum, and modifies it in a number of ways:
  • Simplified for fewer polygons and quicker processing
  • Resized to 60% -- a size that works well for me at 0.2mm layer height
  • Support material added for head pins and tail
  • Pads added at potential problem areas, where prints might tend to peel up. They also join most of the parts together so they can more easily be removed. These can easily be cleaned up with a clipper.
  • Holes are added to the head and tail for a 3mm skewer. I've included no-holes versions as well.
  • It's plated in a couple of different ways for convenience.
  • Output is fixed in netfabb
    • This is a great demo print, too.

Print at 0.2mm layer height -- the pads are 0.2mm high. Clip off the support material from the head pins, and the pads that join the parts together, and assemble. Stick it in your hair, skewer it, and be careful that the person behind you doesn't start eating it off your head. You can remove some of the ribs if you need it shorter.

title: LEGO human optimized for Makergear M3

description.text:
After printing the original Lego Mini Figure by ustkl, I found that probably because of the printer and materials differ, some holes or bosses don't tightly fit LEGO's size.

So I imported the original STL into Fusion 360, modified:

  • neck thicker
  • hip - legs joint boss thicker
  • hip - upper body joint boss thicker
  • hole in the sole of the foot smaller

and now if I print it with Makergear M3 (almost the same as M2 v4 I guess) it perfectly fits LEGOs.

author: gdlseed

description.text:
IMPROVED VERSION HERE. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2544386

This is designed in Fusion360. Uses 2 AA batteries and flickering 3volt candle lights. Use clear PLA for the torch top. PLA for the bottom. Print it with the battery door in place, there is enough of a gap to remove the 2 parts after printing.

You can print the torch bottom and the battery cover together. You will need to pull it apart after it finishes printing. Make sure your first layer is not to low or the battery door and bottom of the torch will get stuck together. you will need to use a small drill bit to clean the hole out for the screw to hold the battery cover in.

For the top of the torch, I print with 2 outside layers and zero infill, just so the torch top can be transparent. You could probably use white filament and it would work.

For the battery holder, I print this AA holder and wired it up and just slide it in and out when the batteries need replaced. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:941081

The torch light top is made with flickering candle lights. I rip the lights apart to scavenge the leds. Wire them up in parallel to the battery and hold the square led part in place with a bit of hot glue.

I used a 12mm push button switch. Like this one https://goo.gl/RZftzz

title: Nerf Elite dart adapter for Nerf Bow

description.text: My son wanted to be able to shoot his elite darts using his Nerf bow, which typically fires large arrows.  We iterated over this design a couple of times, and it seems to shoot well, though not as accurately as a Nerf Elite gun.

The Nerf bow has vent holes on the bottom of the firing "barrel" that need to be blocked.  I did this by wrapping blue tape around the barrel, which also was used to make a nice tight fit with my part.  
The ID of the adapter is just right for the dart... maybe even a little too tight.  We are going to play with ID and length soon to see how they affect the range and accuracy.

comments.text: This adapter works perfectly! I was amazed how well it actually made my old Blazin' Bow... Great job making this!

author: dmatsumoto

description.text:
Hi there!

I recently got a free cabinet which perfectly fits my 3D Printer.
It also has a compartment for mounting filament rolls. All I needed
were proper mounts for the axles, which can be found in my other
project:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2503185

I use the bulky spool holder that came with my Anet A8 along with
this spoolholder:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1998669

The design is great, but needed a bigger diameter for this project,
so I did a small remix.

Beside the change of axle diameter to 10mm, I also added a little
more material around the axle. The new inner axle hole made the
thingy a little unstable (at least for my taste).

Please note that I did not readd a proper thread, as it would not
work well in my use case. Two spool holders are used with a 10mm nut
on each side, so the spool won´t move sideways on the axle and turning
the spool causes the axle to spin.

While printing the filament is unrolling and moving the spool along
with the axle and the nuts. There is no bearing required.

Speaking of bearings: I have the feeling that bearings on a spool holder
are a bad idea in any way, as they may just cause uncontrolled unrolling
on fast print stops or if you intentional pull filament when loading the
extruder. In the end I would add breaks to the holder :D

This is just a simple and "clean" solution that works for me. Maybe it
has some use for others, too.

Many thanks to Jorge Pi (https://www.thingiverse.com/jorgepi/) for the
initial design.

Happy Printing.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

This is a tripod mount that will fit most smartphone sizes. The particularity of this model, apart from its aesthetic appearance, is the mechanical properties of its helical body keeping the top clamp in its axis and leveled according to the adjustment wheel.

To put this tripod mount together you will need in addition:

  • one M6x60 hex screw
  • one M6 hex nut
  • one 1/4-20 nut
  • some piece of cork or foam
  • a super glue to keep the nuts secured in place and to attach the cork or foam

FDM printing recommendations:

For better resistance strength, you should print the helical body standing on the printing bed with support material. However since this piece does not hold the phone, I prefer to print it lying on the printing bed for convenience and smoother result.

comments.text:
